headline: Pick a Stock
summary: It's time for Sunday Journal's 43rd Investment Dartboard contest.

headline: Fed Avoids Saying 'Core Inflation'
summary: As gasoline prices surge, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke is changing his tune when discussing inflation in public—in part to avert criticism that central bankers are out of touch with consumers.

headline: China Hongqiao Secures Funding
summary: Aluminum producer China Hongqiao has secured $350 million in cornerstone investments from four investors for its planned Hong Kong initial public offering.

headline: The Power List
summary: The top business leaders in Asia making headlines last week in select global and regional media. Powered by Dow Jones Factiva and edited for relevance and clarity.

headline: Quake Halts Output Across Japan
summary: Much Japanese manufacturing slowed to a halt following Friday's earthquake and tsunami as auto, steel, electronics and other companies suspended operations.

headline: Europe pact's key points
summary: European finance ministers are meeting here Monday and Tuesday to discuss the fine print of a deal covering the euro zone's bailout funds after euro-zone leaders vaulted over low expectations for an agreement that theyhammered out in the early hours of Saturday morning.

headline: Happening This Week
summary: Happening This Week

headline: Miami-Dade County Mayor Faces Recall Vote
summary: Voters in Miami-Dade County head to the polls Tuesday to decide whether to recall Mayor Carlos Alvarez, a once-popular public figure whose job is on the line after a series of tough decisions.

headline: Riders Contradict Bus-Crash Driver
summary: Passengers and witnesses to a New York City bus crash that killed 14 people are contradicting the driver's story that he was clipped by a tractor-trailer before the accident, an official said.

headline: EU States Duck Financing Challenge
summary: ECB President Jean-Claude Trichet came home from Friday's summit of euro-zone leaders effectively empty-handed, as the leaders again refused to relieve his institution of the burden of keeping struggling banks and member states afloat.

headline: Majority of Zain Board Approves Joint Offer
summary: A majority of the board of Kuwait-based Zain's approved a joint offer Sunday by Saudi's Kingdom Holding and Bahrain's Batelco Group to buy its 25% stake in its Saudi operations.

headline: AT&T Web Customers Face Data Cap
summary: AT&T said it will begin to cap DSL data usage for its Internet customers and implement charges for anyone who exceeds the limit.

headline: Octopus's Mentel on Oil Uncertainty
summary: Lothar Mentel, chief investment officer at Octopus Investments, shares his views on oil with The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Goldman on Its Bankers
summary: Previous filings perhaps had an uncomfortable Las Vegas tinge: "Our goal is to make available to our clients the entire resources of the firm in a seamless fashion, with investment banking serving as front of the house." It's not clear what that made the traders. Croupiers?

headline: Libyan Government Claims Advances Against Rebels
summary: The spokesman for the Libyan armed forces told foreign journalists on Sunday that the government's forces have routed rebels from areas as far east as the coastal town of Brega and predicted swift victory in the city of Benghazi.

headline: U.S. Carriers Resume Japan Flights
summary: American Airlines and Delta had resumed their normal schedules in Japan by Sunday, with no plans to evacuate local employees after Friday's earthquake.

headline: Kan: Biggest Japan Crisis Since WWII
summary: Addressing the nation a little more than 48 hours after the massive shock waves hit, Japan's prime minister said he is confident the nation would overcome the travail.

headline: Earthquake to Hit GDP in Short Term
summary: Japan's massive earthquake and tsunami will slow economic growth to a crawl or even push the economy into contraction over the next quarter or two, but reconstruction efforts should lift the economy by the final months of the year, analysts predict.

headline: What's The Matter With Arsenal?
summary: It will be six years without silverware if the Gunners don't win the English title. How does Arsene Wenger explain his club's lack of trophies?

headline: BYD's Net Fell 34% in 2010
summary: BYD said its 2010 net profit fell 34% as the Chinese battery and car maker, backed by Warren Buffett, contended with fierce competition and a reduction in government incentives for auto purchases.

headline: Japan Responsible for Nuclear Cleanup
summary: The liability costs associated with cleaning up after the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant will ultimately be borne by the Japanese government instead of the private insurance market, according to experts from the insurance industry.

headline: Hardship Worsens for Evacuees
summary: Friday's giant earthquake and tsunami have caused hardship for many Japanese in the past few days. Those who live and work near the star-crossed Fukushima nuclear power facility have borne an even greater burden.

headline: Nomura in Talks to Sell Skylark
summary: Nomura Holdings is in talks to sell Japanese restaurant chain Skylark to U.S. private-equity firm Bain Capital, in a deal that could be worth about $3.62 billion including debt.

headline: Markets Can't Afford This Forgiveness
summary: There is good reason for banks to dig in their heels on a settlement of alleged mortgage-servicing abuses.

headline: Fallout Wouldn't Rival Chernobyl's
summary: Even if the Japanese nuclear plant damaged in the earthquake goes into full meltdown, it is unlikely to cause environmental fallout anything on the scale seen after the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, scientists said.

headline: Residents Struggle for Essentials
summary: In the aftermath of the massive earthquake and tsunami that hammered Japan, residents in the especially hard-hit northeastern regions are struggling to procure essential supplies such as food, water and gasoline.

headline: Analysts See Billions in Insurance Costs
summary: While the cost of Friday's earthquake in Japan is still unknown, the area of the country most directly affected by the quake has about $300 billion of insured property, according to disaster-modeling company AIR Worldwide.

headline: Yen's Gains May Sputter
summary: Buying by speculators may give the yen a further lift in Tokyo trade after Friday's devastating earthquake and tsunami, but dealers generally don't expect the dollar to fall under 80.50 yen.

headline: Japan Struggles to Control Reactors
summary: Japanese officials continued their battle to keep damaged nuclear reactors from overheating in what has become the nation's worst nuclear accident, but said there were no signs of radiation leakage that would accompany a major meltdown.

headline: Stanley Ho's Latest Bluff
summary: Investors in SJM Holdings shouldn't rejoice too much that a family dispute between Stanley Ho and his heirs over control of his empire has been settled. That's because we've heard it before.

headline: Five Killed in West Bank Attack
summary: Five family members were stabbed to death at home late Friday evening by one or more Palestinians who infiltrated the West Bank Jewish settlement of Itamar, Israeli military officers said.

headline: Former Fannie CEO May Face SEC Action
summary: Daniel Mudd, the former chief executive of Fannie Mae, said he has received a Wells notice from the SEC, the latest clue that federal investigators have expanded their years-long probe.

headline: The Beast of the Big East
summary: Behind a performance for the ages by Kemba Walker, Connecticut won its fifth game in five days and survived the nation's toughest conference tournament.

headline: Little Impact to West Coast Ports
summary: Major west coast ports haven't had much operational impact from Japan's earthquake and tsunami Friday.

headline: When Does It Pay to Trade Up Your Technology?
summary: Experts say the pitch for faster, more tricked-out technology has reached a new peak. Here, in four categories, is what you need -- and what you don't.

headline: Why Your Pay Has Gone Up
summary: Nearly half of Americans surveyed didn't know tax-code changes have resulted in a small boost to their wages starting Jan. 1.

headline: Congress Faces Spending Bill Deadline
summary: Congress must pass a spending bill before the current one expires Friday to prevent a government shutdown. Last week, the Senate rejected two bills to fund the remainder of the current fiscal year.

headline: India This Week
summary: Some snapshots of the week gone by in India.

headline: Smart Plays for Your NCAA Pool
summary: Americans are faced with the daunting task of not only predicting which team will win the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament, but which will win each of the 67 games of the three weeks of "March Madness."

headline: Consider Keeping Life Insurance
summary: Changes in estate taxes have prompted some families to consider dropping their life insurance. But for many, there are better options than allowing coverage to lapse.

headline: Working the Graveyard Shift
summary: Working the night shift is a trend that has most likely increased during the recession. That's due, in part, to globalization and the need to work in different time zones and because many companies have opted to add more shifts over hiring more staff or buying new equipment.

headline: Getting Goods on Store Shelves
summary: For entrepreneurs with products to sell, a wide range of sales channels abound. But identifying appropriate retailers -- and striking deals with them -- can be a challenging first-time endeavor.

headline: A Sitter Gets a Cold and the Marriage Sneezes
summary: Sometimes, responsibilities fall along stereotypical gender lines. But that doesn't have to be bad thing, says Katherine Rosman.

headline: How to Be a Killionaire
summary: The odds that capitalism will get anybody where they are today aren't even as good as Powerball, says Al Lewis.

headline: Quake, Tsunami Slam Japan
summary: Northeast Japan was a wasteland after the country's strongest earthquake on record triggered a 30-foot tsunami. The cascade of destruction killed hundreds and forced tens of thousands of people from their homes.

headline: Rescuers Continue to Dig for Survivors
summary: Some of the hardest hit areas of northern Japan remained unreachable and damage to nuclear-power facilities wasn't yet contained—leaving the full extent of the catastrophe still untold.
